channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Magnitude 4.0 earthquake reported near Ukiah, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude 4.0 earthquake was reported at 5:55 p.m. Tuesday 13 miles from Ukiah
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 4.0 earthquake was reported at 5:55 p.m. Tuesday 13 miles from Ukiah

media:content.media:description: A magnitude 4.0 earthquake was reported 13 miles from Ukiah, Calif., on Tuesday.

item.title: SCU Lightning Complex fires burn across five counties in Northern California
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Firefighters on Tuesday battled the SCU Lightning Complex fires in Northern California, made up of about 20 blazes across five counties.
item.content:encoded: Firefighters on Tuesday battled the SCU Lightning Complex fires in Northern California, made up of about 20 blazes across five counties.

item.title: Citing pandemic rules, LAPD refers three party houses for potential utility cuts
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Los Angeles is considering cutting power to at least three homes where large parties have occurred in violation of coronavirus-related rules against social gatherings.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles is considering cutting power to at least three homes where large parties have occurred in violation of coronavirus-related rules against social gatherings.

media:content.media:description: Aerial view of a large house party on Mulholland Drive in Beverly Crest, where three people were shot.

item.title: Slowing COVID-19 outbreak has California weighing what next reopening will look like
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna
item.description: Although Los Angeles County has met the majority of the state's benchmarks to be removed from its watchlist and allow further reopenings, the average number of infections among residents is still too high.
item.content:encoded: Although Los Angeles County has met the majority of the state's benchmarks to be removed from its watchlist and allow further reopenings, the average number of infections among residents is still too high.

media:content.media:description: People visit a beach in front of the Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk during the coronavirus outbreak in Santa Cruz, Calif., Thursday, July 2, 2020. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu)

item.title: L.A. County man accused of voting in three elections as his dead mother
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: Prosecutors charged the 55-year-old with voter fraud, saying he cast ballots from 2012 to 2014 using the identity of his mother, who had died in 2006.
item.content:encoded: Prosecutors charged the 55-year-old with voter fraud, saying he cast ballots from 2012 to 2014 using the identity of his mother, who had died in 2006.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - NOVEMBER 5, 2016 - Eleanor Roosevelt rests below voting booths as people cast their votes at the Los Angeles County Fire Department Lifeguard Operations in Venice on November 5, 2016. Attention Editor: That is the dog's name. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Britney Spears 'strongly opposed' to her father being sole conservator
item.dc:creator: Nardine Saad
item.description: Ahead of a #FreeBritney rally in L.A. on Wednesday, new court documents request that Britney Spears' father, Jamie Spears, be removed as her sole conservator.
item.content:encoded: Ahead of a #FreeBritney rally in L.A. on Wednesday, new court documents request that Britney Spears' father, Jamie Spears, be removed as her sole conservator.

media:content.media:description: Britney Spears is rumored to be in talks to write a novel.

item.title: Complaints against LAPD increased in 2019, but few resulted in discipline
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: The LAPD continued a years-long streak of clearing every single officer accused of biased policing.
item.content:encoded: The LAPD continued a years-long streak of clearing every single officer accused of biased policing.

media:content.media:description: If contract is approved, LAPD officers would get an 8.2% raise over four years.
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Man charged with arson in Ranch 2 fire burning near Azusa homes
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: Prosecutors say a man living in a tent in a riverbed intentionally set the fire that has burned more than 3,000 acres in the Angeles National Forest above Azusa.
item.content:encoded: Prosecutors say a man living in a tent in a riverbed intentionally set the fire that has burned more than 3,000 acres in the Angeles National Forest above Azusa.

media:content.media:description: A firefighting helicopter makes an approach to drop water on the Ranch fire in the hills above a cluster of homes along the San Gabriel River near Azusa.

item.title: L.A. councilman wants to stop hotels from housing migrant children
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: L.A. City Councilman Gil Cedillo wants to stop hotels from being used by private security firms to house and detain migrant children or families.
item.content:encoded: L.A. City Councilman Gil Cedillo wants to stop hotels from being used by private security firms to house and detain migrant children or families.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- WEDNESDAY, JUNE 28, 2017: Councilmember Gil Cedillo questions members of the Department of Water and Power (DWP) Board of Water and Power Commissioners before the city council voted 11-3 to approve a pay increase over 5 years for 9,000 union workers from the Department of Water and Power at Los Angeles City Hall Wednesday, June 28, 2017. The contract was opposed by some neighborhood activists who argued that it was rushed through without enough scrutiny. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Newsom declares statewide emergency as fires burn across California
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Leila Miller, Taryn Luna
item.description: More than 30 wildfires are burning across California, including nearly a dozen that started in the last two days.
item.content:encoded: More than 30 wildfires are burning across California, including nearly a dozen that started in the last two days.

media:content.media:description: Piru, CA, Monday, August 17, 2020 - The Holser Fire consumed more than 1,000 acres by the end of its first day just East of Lake Piru. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Isolation, confusion: What the COVID-19 pandemic is like for people with dementia
item.dc:creator: Heidi de Marco
item.description: Changes wrought by the COVID-19 pandemic have upended the lives of millions of dementia patients and their caregivers, who rely on long-standing routines.
item.content:encoded: Changes wrought by the COVID-19 pandemic have upended the lives of millions of dementia patients and their caregivers, who rely on long-standing routines.

media:content.media:description: Daisy Conant hasn't been diagnosed with dementia, but she has a family history of Alzheimer's and exhibits clear signs of memory loss. She gets frustrated reading news about the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: California to join legal challenge against Trump administration over USPS reductions
item.dc:creator: Maya Lau
item.description: The move comes as the postmaster general backs off changes for now. California's attorney general calls the changes an attack on a fair election.
item.content:encoded: The move comes as the postmaster general backs off changes for now. California's attorney general calls the changes an attack on a fair election.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Dec. 4, 2019, file photo, California Attorney General Xavier Becerra talk during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif. Attorneys general in 20 states and the District of Columbia sued the Trump administration on Tuesday, July 21, 2020, alleging that new federal rules undermine their ability to protect rivers, lakes and streams within their borders. "The Trump administration wants to clear the deck for fossil fuel infrastructure," Becerra alleged in announcing the legal action, the latest of dozens he has filed against the administration. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli,File)

item.title: Grace MontaÃ±ez Davis, former L.A. deputy mayor and Eastside political activist, dies at 93
item.dc:creator: Dorany Pineda, Gustavo Arellano
item.description: Grace MontaÃ±ez Davis, who served as deputy mayor for Tom Bradley and was the highest ranking woman and Latina during his administration, was 93.
item.content:encoded: Grace MontaÃ±ez Davis, who served as deputy mayor for Tom Bradley and was the highest ranking woman and Latina during his administration, was 93.

media:content.media:description: Grace MontaÃ±ez Davis served as deputy mayor for Tom Bradley from 1975 until 1990.

item.title: New rolling blackouts 'imminent' as California heat wave intensifies
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller, Alex Wigglesworth, Sammy Roth
item.description: State officials are continuing to urge conservation in an effort to reduce the need for power outages as the state's heat wave peaks.
item.content:encoded: State officials are continuing to urge conservation in an effort to reduce the need for power outages as the state's heat wave peaks.

media:content.media:description: The thermometer at Calvary Church in Woodland Hills registers 106 degree's Monday.

item.title: Does L.A. count its homeless, or make its best guess? A little of both, it turns out
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith
item.description: Keeping track of the number of people who are homeless in Los Angeles is an exercise in uncertainty. Not only do the numbers change from year to year, presumably reflecting real shifts in the homeless population, but, once published, they can still change months or years later â based on changes in how the numbers are calculated.
item.content:encoded: Keeping track of the number of people who are homeless in Los Angeles is an exercise in uncertainty. Not only do the numbers change from year to year, presumably reflecting real shifts in the homeless population, but, once published, they can still change months or years later â based on changes in how the numbers are calculated.

media:content.media:description: NORTH HOLLYWOOD, CA - JANUARY 21, 2020 - Gospel musician Clemmie Williams, 34, lives homeless in North Hollywood Park on January 21, 2020. Williams has been working on part time jobs but it's not enough to make first and last for an apartment he says. "It's a struggle to get back to normalcy," Williams said. Williams was photographed on the first night of the 2020 LA County homeless count. On Tuesday, volunteers with the focused on the San Gabriel and San Fernando valleys. Other swaths of the region, such as the South Bay and Antelope Valley, will be covered Wednesday and Thursday.. The homeless count is overseen by the Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority (LAHSA) The volunteers will canvas more than 80 cities and 200 communities across L.A. County over three days to count the number of homeless people living on the streets, according to the LAHSA. Last year's count found that nearly 59,000 people were experiencing homelessness countywide, an increase of 12% from 2018. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Victims of Golden State Killer finally confront him in court with stories of pain and survival
item.dc:creator: Paige St. John, Luke Money
item.description: Victims of Joseph James DeAngelo Jr. will spend three days telling the court about the impact of his crimes before he is sentenced Friday.
item.content:encoded: Victims of Joseph James DeAngelo Jr. will spend three days telling the court about the impact of his crimes before he is sentenced Friday.

media:content.media:description: The victims of Joseph James DeAngelo Jr., the former police officer whose violent crimes through the 1970s and 1980s terrorized Californians across the state and earned him the moniker Golden State Killer, finally get their say in court beginning Tuesday, August 18, 2020.

item.title: L.A. County issues strict rules for colleges reopening during coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe, Nina Agrawal
item.description: After months of waiting, L.A. County colleges received public health rules for fall reopenings: virtually no in-person classes and very limited on-campus housing.
item.content:encoded: After months of waiting, L.A. County colleges received public health rules for fall reopenings: virtually no in-person classes and very limited on-campus housing.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 17, 2020 - - USC student Mitchell Steimle, 21, from left, and his brother Anthony, 18, participate in a wellness check conducted by Campus Health and Screening Ambassadors Sonya Melendez-Fitzgerald, 54, and Ethan Perreira, 21, right, on the first day of academic instruction at USC for the Fall 2020 semester in Los Angeles on August 17, 2020. All students who visit the campus have to go through a wellness check, answer questions regarding COVID-19 symptoms and have their temperature checked before they are allowed to enter campus. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: From 'firenadoes' to record heat, California extreme weather a glimpse of future
item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza, Louis Sahagun, Joseph Serna
item.description: As one of the worst heat waves in years continues to broil California, millions are experiencing the havoc that ensues with the type of extreme weather that is growing more frequent with climate change.
item.content:encoded: As one of the worst heat waves in years continues to broil California, millions are experiencing the havoc that ensues with the type of extreme weather that is growing more frequent with climate change.

media:content.media:description: Lightning forks over the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge as a storm passes over Oakland, Calif., Sunday, Aug. 16, 2020. Numerous lightning strikes early Sunday sparked brush fires throughout the region. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

item.title: 'Are we ready?' LAUSD's first day back to school, online and on Zoom, is anything but normal
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Paloma Esquivel, Andrew J. Campa
item.description: The L.A. Unified School District opens online Tuesday. But the typical excitement is tempered by families' anxiety and confusion as educators try to offer a 'normal' school day that is anything but amid the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. Unified School District opens online Tuesday. But the typical excitement is tempered by families' anxiety and confusion as educators try to offer a 'normal' school day that is anything but amid the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: WALNUT PARK, CA - AUGUST 13: Xavier Reyes, founder of Alta Public Schools, shows the reduced size and increased spacing in classrooms at Academia Moderna in Walnut Park. The school will reopen with a staggered schedule and smaller class sizes. Photographed at Academia Moderna on Thursday, Aug. 13, 2020 in Walnut Park, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Police reform advocates scrutinize police unions, calling them obstacles to reform
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Police reform advocates who for years have searched for roadblocks to accountability have zeroed in on a new target: police unions.
item.content:encoded: Police reform advocates who for years have searched for roadblocks to accountability have zeroed in on a new target: police unions.

media:content.media:description: FILE Ã¢ÂÂ In this March 26, 2016, file photo, Black Lives Matter activist DeRay Mckesson, chatting with campaign volunteers in Baltimore. A federal lawsuit accuses Black Lives Matter and several movement leaders of inciting violence that led to a gunman's deadly ambush of law enforcement officers in Baton Rouge last summer. Mckesson and four other Black Lives Matter leaders are named as defendants in the suit filed Friday on behalf of one of the officers wounded in the July 17 attack by a black military veteran, who killed three other officers before he was shot dead. (AP Photo/Patrick Semansky, File)

item.title: Overruling Cal State trustees, Newsom approves new ethnic studies requirement
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom signed legislation that makes ethnic studies a graduation requirement across the California State University's 23 campuses.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom signed legislation that makes ethnic studies a graduation requirement across the California State University's 23 campuses.

media:content.media:description: A banner hangs from an upper-floor railing as students demonstrate at Cal State L.A. in support of the ethnic studies programs.

item.title: Firefighters combat several dozen fires in Butte County
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Firefighters battled several dozen fires Monday in Butte County.
item.content:encoded: Firefighters battled several dozen fires Monday in Butte County.

media:content.media:description: Oroville CHP units are closely monitoring the fire in the Potters Ravine area.

item.title: As California clears backlog of COVID-19 cases, deaths hit a low for the month
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom said San Diego County, the state's second largest, could be taken off the watchlist this week.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom said San Diego County, the state's second largest, could be taken off the watchlist this week.

media:content.media:description: SYLMAR, CA - AUGUST 17: Ian Roistacher and his brother Mitch Roistacher, 4, walk back to their hotel room after picking up back-to-school supplies for Ian's three younger brothers during a fair at the Vagabond Inn in Sylmar on Monday, Aug. 17, 2020. The event, on the first day of school, was a partnership between Councilwoman Monica Rodriguez and L.A. Family Housing providing students with backpacks full of school supplies and other essential items for the family. The families participating are those facing economic hardship because of the pandemic. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's top court caps penalties on nursing homes to $500 for certain lawsuits
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Ruling on a 1982 law, the California Supreme Court has limited damages against nursing homes to $500 per lawsuit, a victory for the industry amid the coronavirus crisis.
item.content:encoded: Ruling on a 1982 law, the California Supreme Court has limited damages against nursing homes to $500 per lawsuit, a victory for the industry amid the coronavirus crisis.

media:content.media:description: California Supreme Court Justice Mariano-Florentino CuÃ©llar, seen in January, wrote the 4-3 ruling that said a government agency's legal bills are generally public record in cases that have been resolved.
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times

item.title: California's first plague case in 5 years is confirmed in South Lake Tahoe
item.description: El Dorado County officials said Monday that the California Department of Public Health notified them of the positive test of a resident who is under medical care while recovering at home.
item.content:encoded: El Dorado County officials said Monday that the California Department of Public Health notified them of the positive test of a resident who is under medical care while recovering at home.

media:content.media:description: KINGS BEACH, CA -- MAY 07: The north shore of Lake Tahoe on Thursday, May 7, 2020, in Kings Beach, CA. Cities and counties that live off tourism are strategizing for how to prepare for an influx in out-of-towners when coronavirus restrictions are lifted. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Prosecutors challenge Golden State Killer's apparent frailty, say he chooses not to show remorse
item.dc:creator: Paige St. John
item.description: Jailhouse videos belie Joseph James DeAngelo Jr.'s appearances in court as a feeble, frail old man, prosecutors say.
item.content:encoded: Jailhouse videos belie Joseph James DeAngelo Jr.'s appearances in court as a feeble, frail old man, prosecutors say.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this June 1, 2018, file, pool photo, Joseph James DeAngelo appears in Sacramento Superior Court, in Sacramento, Calif. Authorities have cleared DeAngelo accused of being California's Golden State Killer of involvement in the 1975 murder of a 14-year-old girl in the Central Valley. The Tulare County district attorney's office on Tuesday, Jan. 8, 2019, released a review that said DNA testing concluded that DeAngelo didn't kill Donna Jo Richmond. (Jose Luis Villegas/The Sacramento Bee via AP, Pool, File)

item.title: Earthquake: 3.3 quake reported near Fremont, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: The magnitude 3.3 earthquake at 1:27 p.m. Monday was centered two miles from Fremont, four miles from San Jose and eight miles from Santa Clara, Calif.
item.content:encoded: The magnitude 3.3 earthquake at 1:27 p.m. Monday was centered two miles from Fremont, four miles from San Jose and eight miles from Santa Clara, Calif.

media:content.media:description: A magnitude 3.3 earthquake was reported Monday afternoon at 1:27 p.m. Pacific time two miles from Fremont, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: More California counties make state coronavirus watchlist as Santa Cruz is removed
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna, Colleen Shalby
item.description: On Monday, California updated its list of counties subject to business closures due to high rates of COVID-19 transmission. Just one county, Santa Cruz, was removed.
item.content:encoded: On Monday, California updated its list of counties subject to business closures due to high rates of COVID-19 transmission. Just one county, Santa Cruz, was removed.

media:content.media:description: California Governor Gavin Newsom speaks to members of the press at a news conference in Sacramento, Calif., Thursday, Feb. 27, 2020. Newsom spoke about the state's response to novel coronavirus, also known as COVID-19. Behind him are Director of the Governor's Office of Emergency Services Mark Ghilarducci, right, and California Department of Public Health Director and State Health Officer Dr. Sonia Angell. Yesterday, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention confirmed a possible first case of person-to-person transmission of COVID-19 in California in the general public.(AP Photo/Randall Benton)

item.title: Trump sought to withhold California fire aid because of politics, former official says
item.dc:creator: Noah Bierman, Eli Stokols
item.description: Former Homeland Security chief of staff says in a campaign ad that Trump tried to block aid to California fire victims out of "rage" at opponents in state.
item.content:encoded: Former Homeland Security chief of staff says in a campaign ad that Trump tried to block aid to California fire victims out of "rage" at opponents in state.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CALIF. -- TUESDAY, DECEMBER 5, 2017: Brandon Baker, center and Prescott McKenzie, right, take cover from the flying embers during a brush fire in Ventura, Calif., on Dec. 5, 2017. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: These nurses work in a hospital 'hot zone.' The virus stalks them as they return home
item.dc:creator: Stefanie Dazio
item.description: The AP followed four nurses working in the coronavirus unit at St. Jude's Medical Center in Fullerton. Nurses fear for their families after their shifts end.
item.content:encoded: The AP followed four nurses working in the coronavirus unit at St. Jude's Medical Center in Fullerton. Nurses fear for their families after their shifts end.

media:content.media:description: Romelia Navarro, right, is comforted by nurse Michele Younkin as she weeps while sitting at the bedside of her dying husband, Antonio, in St. Jude Medical Center's COVID-19 unit in Fullerton, Calif., Friday, July 31, 2020. Antonio was Younkin's first COVID-19 patient to pass on her watch. (AP Photo/Jae C. Hong)

item.title: Admissions scandal: Prosecutors want 2 months in prison for Lori Loughlin, 5 months for husband
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: College admissions scandal prosecutors recommend Lori Loughlin and J. Mossimo Giannulli be sentenced to two and five months, respectively, in prison.
item.content:encoded: College admissions scandal prosecutors recommend Lori Loughlin and J. Mossimo Giannulli be sentenced to two and five months, respectively, in prison.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this April 3, 2019 file photo, actress Lori Loughlin, front, and husband, clothing designer Mossimo Giannulli, left, depart federal court in Boston after facing charges in a nationwide college admissions bribery scandal. Loughlin and her husband Giannulli said in court documents Monday, April 15, 2019, that they are pleading not guilty to charges that they took part in a sweeping college admissions bribery scam. (AP Photo/Steven Senne, File)

item.title: Unemployment fraud ring filed bogus California jobless benefits for inmates, officials say

item.content:encoded: The state's inspector general says screening and training problems may have contributed to the deadly outbreaks in California prisons.

media:content.media:description: Chino, CA, Tuesday, July 21, 2020 - Outside the California Institute for Men, Chino. The Chino prison reported more than 600 cases of COVID-19 and nine deaths. The 700 inmates selected for transfer had medical conditions that made them especially vulnerable to the virus. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.description: Gavin Newsom's potential route to the White House has been abruptly blocked by Kamala Harris' ascent to the Democratic vice presidential slot.

media:content.media:description: Sen. Kamala Harris, left, endorses California Lt. Gov. Gavin Newsom for the 2018 California Governor's race at the Ronald Tutor Campus Center at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles, Friday, Feb. 16, 2018. (AP Photo/Damian Dovarganes)

item.title: Death Valley hits 130 degrees, thought to be highest temperature on Earth in nearly a century
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: Death Valley may have recorded Earth's highest temperature in 90 years. Data show it is also be among the top three highest temperatures ever measured in Death Valley.
item.content:encoded: Death Valley may have recorded Earth's highest temperature in 90 years. Data show it is also be among the top three highest temperatures ever measured in Death Valley.

media:content.media:description: Death Valley was a film location for "Star Wars" scenes, and now you can find out where with help from a free map.

item.title: L.A. schools announce massive COVID-19 testing, tracing initiative for all students and staff
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Laura Newberry
item.description: L.A. schools have launched a massive COVID-19 testing program in hopes of reopening campuses.
item.content:encoded: L.A. schools have launched a massive COVID-19 testing program in hopes of reopening campuses.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 07: Los Angeles Unified School District staff member Adrian Pacheco demonstrates the use of sanitizing tools as LAUSD Superintendent Austin Beutner takes a tour of Burbank Middle School with Principal Christine Moore on Friday, Aug. 7, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. As the academic school year looms, preparations have been under way to make campuses safe inside and out, even though the school year will start with distance-learning only because of the surging coronavirus pandemic. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California power grid manager urges residents to conserve energy amid intense heat wave
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: The heat "is causing a strain on supplies, and consumers should be prepared for likely rolling outages during the late afternoons and early evenings through Wednesday," the California Independent System Operator said in its statewide flex alert Sunday.
item.content:encoded: The heat "is causing a strain on supplies, and consumers should be prepared for likely rolling outages during the late afternoons and early evenings through Wednesday," the California Independent System Operator said in its statewide flex alert Sunday.

media:content.media:description: A jogger runs in extreme heat under high tension electrical lines in the North Hollywood section of Los Angeles on Saturday, Aug. 15, 2020. California has ordered rolling power outages for the first time since 2001 as a statewide heat wave strained its electrical system. (AP Photo/Richard Vogel)

item.title: Reporting backlog continues to affect L.A. County COVID-19 case numbers
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 1,192 new cases of the coronavirus and nine related deaths but said both numbers were artificially low due to a weekend reporting lag.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 1,192 new cases of the coronavirus and nine related deaths but said both numbers were artificially low due to a weekend reporting lag.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA - AUGUST 12, 2020 - -Richard Hernandes, from right to left, his girlfriend Jazmin Domingo, his brothers Seth Patlan, 5, and Joseph Hamassian, heed the, "Masks Up, Surf City," banner campaign to prevent coronavirus on Main Street in Huntington Beach on August 12, 2020. The campaign, a play on the phrase "Surf's Up," includes 100 pennants, a banner at the pier and digital displays citywide, Huntington Beach spokeswoman Catherine Jun said. Fifty pennants were installed downtown on Aug. 6. The remaining signs are in production this week, and 13 pennants and a banner are expected to be installed on the Huntington Beach Pier. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Massive wildfire spawns fire tornadoes in Northern California

item.description: Videos posted to social media showed twister-like formations in the path of the Loyalton fire, which started Friday evening in the Tahoe National Forest.
item.content:encoded: Videos posted to social media showed twister-like formations in the path of the Loyalton fire, which started Friday evening in the Tahoe National Forest.

item.title: Federal judge orders COVID-19 testing at Bakersfield immigration detention facility

item.content:encoded: Judge orders COVID-19 testing at Bakersfield immigration detention center where a spreading outbreak was met with 'deliberate indifference' for weeks.

item.title: Column One: Nearly half a century ago, activists 'invaded' this California island by claiming it for Mexico
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: In 1972, the mission of the Brown Berets was to occupy Catalina Island â land they believed belonged to Mexico. Nearly 48 years later, Chicano leader David Sanchez revisits the island and the legacy of the Berets' three-week occupation.
item.content:encoded: In 1972, the mission of the Brown Berets was to occupy Catalina Island â land they believed belonged to Mexico. Nearly 48 years later, Chicano leader David Sanchez revisits the island and the legacy of the Berets' three-week occupation.

media:content.media:description: CATALINA ISLAND, CA - AUGUST 07: Activist David Sanchez, of Huntington Park, who led the Brown Berets during the occupational protest in Catalina Island in 1972 as part of the Chicano Moratorium, revisit the point where he once protested in Avalon Friday, Aug. 7, 2020 in Catalina Island. The group of 26 planted a large Mexican flag on the point, referred to as Burrito Point by some locals, above the Chimes Tower and claimed the island in the name of Mexico. The Brown Berets are a pro-Chicano organization that emerged during the Chicano Movement in the late1960s to address the issues of educational reform, farm workers' rights, police brutality, anti-war activities and other problems confronting the Chicano community and was founded by Sanchez. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus complicates California's worst power shortage in two decades
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Jack Dolan
item.description: People staying home with air conditioners blasting, plus a dearth of power from other states results in the worst statewide energy shortage in nearly 20 years
item.content:encoded: People staying home with air conditioners blasting, plus a dearth of power from other states results in the worst statewide energy shortage in nearly 20 years

media:content.media:description: The thermometer at Calvary Church in Woodland Hills registers 106 degree's Monday.

item.title: 'Agent of colonialism' or a 'saint for our times'? Junipero Serra's legacy divides Latinos
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: Latinos have served as the most vocal detractors and defenders of JunÃ­pero Serra over the last few months in a fierce debate about the saint's legacy.
item.content:encoded: Latinos have served as the most vocal detractors and defenders of JunÃ­pero Serra over the last few months in a fierce debate about the saint's legacy.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - AUGUST 01: Veronica Valadez, 46, stands for a portrait where a statue of Fr. Juniper Serra once stood in front of Ventura city hall on Saturday, Aug. 1, 2020 in Ventura, CA. Valadez is one of several Latino detractors of Fr. Junipero Serra and believes the saint's work to convert local indigenous groups and build the California Mission system was oppressive, destructive of local cultures and led to many deaths of indigenous peoples. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Los Angeles County reports more than 2,100 new coronavirus cases and 35 more related deaths
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith
item.description: The new numbers brought the county's totals to 220,762 positive cases of COVID-19 and 5,245 deaths. Saturday's death total was the lowest of any day this week.
item.content:encoded: The new numbers brought the county's totals to 220,762 positive cases of COVID-19 and 5,245 deaths. Saturday's death total was the lowest of any day this week.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 08: EMT Hannah Mikus, right, demonstrates how to self administer the test to drivers during Coronavirus Covid-19 testing in LA County at the Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science in South Los Angeles on July 8, 2020 as California records its highest single-day coronavirus death toll with 149 fatalities reported. The Charles R. Drew University site has tested a large number of people from racial and ethnic minority groups that are at higher risk for poor outcomes and complications from COVID-19. Drew University on Wednesday, July 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: State's freeze of COVID-19 watchlist magnifies breakdown in communication to counties
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The state's coronavirus watchlist, which guides its decision to allow counties to open certain sectors, including schools and in-person worship, was frozen last week after state officials announced that a test result backlog had led to an inaccurate case count.
item.content:encoded: The state's coronavirus watchlist, which guides its decision to allow counties to open certain sectors, including schools and in-person worship, was frozen last week after state officials announced that a test result backlog had led to an inaccurate case count.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA - AUGUST 12, 2020 - - A couple walk past a sign that reads, "Please Wear Mask," in front of Dash of Sass clothing store along Main Street during a "Masks Up, Surf City," banner campaign to prevent coronavirus in the city of Huntington Beach on August 12, 2020. Customers are not allowed into the store unless they are wearing a mask. The campaign, a play on the phrase "Surf's Up," includes 100 pennants, a banner at the pier and digital displays citywide, Huntington Beach spokeswoman Catherine Jun said. Fifty pennants were installed downtown on Aug. 6. The remaining signs are in production this week, and 13 pennants and a banner are expected to be installed on the Huntington Beach Pier. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: Long Beach mayor Robert Garcia (right) holds his mother's hand during her wedding as Greg O'Donnell's mother holds his. Gaby and Greg O'Donnell both died due to complications from COVID-19.

item.title: Column: I wasn't a fan of Kamala Harris. It took President Trump to change my mind

item.title: A beloved L.A. bakery's fight to survive the coronavirus reminds us to help out places we'd miss
item.dc:creator: Nita Lelyveld
item.description: Diamond Bakery on L.A.'s Fairfax Ave. has survived a lot over 74 years. Loyal customers and a GoFundMe campaign hope to carry it through the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Diamond Bakery on L.A.'s Fairfax Ave. has survived a lot over 74 years. Loyal customers and a GoFundMe campaign hope to carry it through the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 12: Alexes (cq) Luna helps a customer at Diamond Bakery on Fairfax Avenue. The store has been around since 1946 but its sales have plummeted because of the pandemic. A GoFundMe campaign was started to help pay the bills and to keep from having to lay off employees. Photographed at Diamond Bakery on Wednesday, Aug. 12, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Low-wage workers face retaliation for demanding COVID-19 safety measures at work
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Some of the state's largest coronavirus outbreaks have occurred in workplaces, but fear of retaliation is preventing employees from voicing safety concerns, workers and labor organizers say.
item.content:encoded: Some of the state's largest coronavirus outbreaks have occurred in workplaces, but fear of retaliation is preventing employees from voicing safety concerns, workers and labor organizers say.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 30: Lizett Aguilar poses for a portrait outside of her home in East Los Angeles on Thursday, July 30, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Aguilar said that after she helped lead strikes at a Domino's in Boyle Heights over unsafe working conditions, her supervisor retaliated against her by making her job more onerous. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California heat wave may rival deadly July 2006 event, forecasters say
item.dc:creator: Paul Duginski
item.description: High pressure will reach a strength that occurs only about once every 10 years, the National Weather Service said, fueling a heat wave that could rival the seven-day event in 2006 that researchers connected to hundreds of deaths.
item.content:encoded: High pressure will reach a strength that occurs only about once every 10 years, the National Weather Service said, fueling a heat wave that could rival the seven-day event in 2006 that researchers connected to hundreds of deaths.

media:content.media:description: The extended outlook calls for temperatures to continue to be above normal in California and the Southwest.

item.title: Some evacuation orders lifted as firefighters continue battle on Lake fire
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Officials lifted additional evacuation orders that had been put in place Friday evening for Antelope Valley residents. Previously declared evacuation orders were maintained, however, as the Lake fire continued to pose a threat.
item.content:encoded: Officials lifted additional evacuation orders that had been put in place Friday evening for Antelope Valley residents. Previously declared evacuation orders were maintained, however, as the Lake fire continued to pose a threat.

media:content.media:description: LAKE HUGHES, CA. August 12, 2020: A fast-moving brush fire blacked 400 acres in an hour this afternoon in Lake Hughes, and fire officials said it had the potential to burn 1,000 acres. The Lake Fire was reported at about 3:30 p.m. near North Lake Hughes Road and Pine Canyon Road in the Angeles National Forest, according to Marvin Lim of the Los Angeles County Fire Department, which was battling the blaze with Angeles National Forest crews. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles)

item.description: Earlier, Grace Community Church in Sun Valley filed suit against state and county officials, including Gov. Gavin Newsom and L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti.
item.content:encoded: Earlier, Grace Community Church in Sun Valley filed suit against state and county officials, including Gov. Gavin Newsom and L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti.

item.title: Jackie Lacey's husband claims state charges against him in gun case are improper
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: David Lacey, the husband of Los Angeles County's district attorney, seeks to have charges that he pointed a gun at protesters at his door dismissed.
item.content:encoded: David Lacey, the husband of Los Angeles County's district attorney, seeks to have charges that he pointed a gun at protesters at his door dismissed.

media:content.media:description: This video still image provided by Dahlia Ferlito shows Los Angeles County District Attorney Jackie Lacey's husband David Lacey pointing a gun at Black Lives Matter protesters outside their home in the Granada Hills section of Los Angeles on Monday, March 2, 2020. The first black woman to lead the largest local prosecutor's office in the U.S. apologized for her husband pointing the gun at Black Lives Matter demonstrators who came to their Los Angeles home before dawn Monday. (Dahlia Ferlito via AP)

item.title: Watch: Lake fire spawns 'terrifying' fire tornado as it burns through Angeles National Forest
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The National Weather Service called the Lake fire tornado, or fire whirl, 'an impressive and terrifying example of extreme fire behavior.'
item.content:encoded: The National Weather Service called the Lake fire tornado, or fire whirl, 'an impressive and terrifying example of extreme fire behavior.'

item.title: California oil production limits stall in Legislature, leaving the issue to Newsom
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: Legislation to put mandated minimum space between oil wells and homes, as well as schools and playgrounds, failed passage in a California Senate committee.
item.content:encoded: Legislation to put mandated minimum space between oil wells and homes, as well as schools and playgrounds, failed passage in a California Senate committee.

media:content.media:description: McKittrick, California, CALIFORNIA-APRIL 29, 2020-There are over 1,100 producing oil wells in the McKittrick oil field, just north of the town of McKittrick on Cal. State Route 33. With the falling price of oil, some pumpjacks that need repair are being left idle. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Team is researching at-home coronavirus testing, Garcetti says
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith
item.description: A coalition of scientific experts, bioscience firms, government leaders and foundations is researching at-home coronavirus testing, L.A. mayor says.
item.content:encoded: A coalition of scientific experts, bioscience firms, government leaders and foundations is researching at-home coronavirus testing, L.A. mayor says.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 27: Mayor Eric Garcetti speaks during a press conference to announce the expansion of LAPD's signature community policing program in City Hall on Monday, July 27, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Suspected MS-13 leader's capture offers window into gang's structure
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Nelson "Mula" Flores, who authorities say is one of MS-13's most influential members outside El Salvador, is taken into U.S. custody.
item.content:encoded: Nelson "Mula" Flores, who authorities say is one of MS-13's most influential members outside El Salvador, is taken into U.S. custody.

media:content.media:description: Nelson Alexander Flores, known as 'Mula,' is charged in Columbus with extortion and money laundering.

item.title: Sheriff Villanueva to fire or suspend 26 people involved in off-duty Banditos fight
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva moves to fire or suspend 26 employees over a 2018 fight associated with the Banditos clique.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva moves to fire or suspend 26 employees over a 2018 fight associated with the Banditos clique.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 12: Sheriff Alex Villanueva speaks at a news conference to give an update on the fatal shooting by a deputy of Andres Guardado on June 18 near Gardena. in Hall of Justice on Wednesday, Aug. 12, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California on the cusp of reining in COVID-19 surge, data show
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Statewide in California, the transmission rate of COVID-19 has stabilized or is falling, and hospitalization rates are also dropping.
item.content:encoded: Statewide in California, the transmission rate of COVID-19 has stabilized or is falling, and hospitalization rates are also dropping.

media:content.media:description: VENICE, CA - AUGUST 09, 2020: People wear protective masks against the coronavirus while making their way along the bicycle path in Venice Beach. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Back to school in a pandemic: Resources and news for parents
item.description: The new school year of remote learning will bring unique challenges. Here are guides to help parents of school-age children navigate remote learning, as well as recent updates about education in Southern California.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 07: Labels on desks designate where students can sit with respect to social distancing as Los Angeles Unified School District Superintendent Austin Beutner takes a tour of Burbank Middle School with Principal Christine Moore on Friday, Aug. 7, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. As the academic school year looms, preparations have been under way to make campuses safe inside and out, even though the school year will start with distance-learning only because of the surging coronavirus pandemic. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: What can parents who work outside the home do about remote schooling?
item.dc:creator: Lila Seidman
item.description: Remote learning is a challenge for parents who have to leave home for work. Here's a guide to some of the options
item.content:encoded: Remote learning is a challenge for parents who have to leave home for work. Here's a guide to some of the options

media:content.media:description: TORRANCE, CA - APRIL 27: Vons store supervisor Anthony Capone, right, greets shoppers as they are allowed in at 7 a.m. to the Vons located at 24325 Crenshaw Blvd in Torrance. Doors opened at 6 a.m. for seniors and at-risk shoppers due to the Coronavirus. Most of the team arrives at 5 a.m. to stock the shelves with product, sanitize the location for staff and shoppers, and picker/shoppers begin to collect items for .com home delivery shoppers. Vendors arriving throughout the morning must read a checklist of warnings, sign in and they must wear face covering. Vons on Monday, April 27, 2020 in Torrance, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Back to school in a pandemic: The basics of remote learning
item.dc:creator: Faith E. Pinho
item.description: Here's how to get help with technology, including computers, WiFi and free meals, from your school district.
item.content:encoded: Here's how to get help with technology, including computers, WiFi and free meals, from your school district.

media:content.media:description: LYNWOOD, CA - APRIL 23, 2020: Kahlinah (cq) Garrett, an office assistant at Hosler Middle School in Lynwood, helps distribute computers on Thursday, April 23, 2020. Remote digital learning has become a necessity during the coronavirus pandemic. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times
